text: Dear Antonio, I am not ready for MVC at the moment. I want to learn Javascript and html for the front end an enjoy that backend does not need any learning. I plan to use MVC later.
I am working at the moment on SEAMAP as I need the solution for my daily work:

I remember the time when I did not know how to make projects and pass parameters in Fivewin.
At the time I made a program that added different  files before compiling. I could just use // <include myincfile.inc> in the source code. At the end I had a PRG file. I think that until I know mod harbour better my alternative is easiest for me.

Dear friends, I would suggest that mod harbour development be divided into 2 directions: mod harbor light and mod harbor professional.
mod harbor light should address the "dBase / Clipper" programmer. We should have simple examples: address management, simple billing, a cash book, and a simple forum.
mod harbor is currently the only tool that really supports DBF files on the web. And there are still many DBF files! What do you think?
and mod harbour light is ready - there are only missing these templates.
account book for private use - my next project

Since the beginning of the project there are these 2 addresses. Everyone is free to use the address they want and I don't think you should say that "dbase / Clipper" programmers should choose the "light" way as you say.
If you feel comfortable with your prg and includes prg's, you are free to take this way, but each one of us is already old enough to choose what is best for him.

Charly I understand well and I am sure I will use MVC later. But I will remember that Antonio posted that getting mod harbour users is the most important thing at the moment. You can only address new users if the learning curve is not steep or if you present them results which attracts them.

<@UJHD6A81H> No one says otherwise. A new user that starts with mod harbor has a lot of examples to test and test. But you cannot say that "Harbour users" must choose the "light" way to work with mod harbor. No one here forces anything, only you who seem to want to just work in one direction. You only start projects and projects, but I haven't seen any closed yet. I am anxious and looking forward to seeing a closed application doing it as you propose (in my opinion, a wrong way to make applications on the web) but I have always respected your way of doing things, unlike you...
Charly for example here is one which is working very hard every day since I released it.
<http://itarraco.com/tweb.forum/viewtopic.php?f=13&t=168>
:slightly_smiling_face:
I think you know the framework used - TWeb

Uhmmm TWeb I remember this nice tool :wink:, and I know what you did with it, but Otto ... now I'm talking about mod_harbour. I am helping everyone who asks me for help, but I never, never tell them ... The best way is the "light". I only say to you: Have you created an application in mod_harbour? (an application, not a prg with dummy grid). Have you been able to compare the way to make an application in one way or another? If you have done it then I will not tell you anything, but otherwise I must say it. Why ? Because sometimes I think it is to give wrong expectations to other users and that is why I am telling you now.

I think a harbour user who normally wants to make data management applications (usually, of course). However simple you make an application (data authentication, maintenance of a table, data editing, data validation, ...) you cannot tell them that they will get it with a spagetti code, because then they will realize the reality and you will see that it is chaos.
That is why I think you shouldn't  say which is the best way and more without having closed any application in mod harbor...
And from the beginning I have always said that everyone is free to do what they want, of course...
but GENESIS shows how to do
mod harbour can do all what PHP can
do for you
It's not true
why
Because php now is most robust, have a lot of tools, commands, options, security,...
it is the reality
but i u want to think other thing...
you can use that all from mod harbour to
I only see the advatages from mod harbour and you what is missing
Otto, i don't have more time, sorry. At beginning i said to you: I u are happy, i'm happy too
I you want your applications of your way, i like to see when you finish one as you have done
Hey, I have lots of unclosed examples in mod_harbour :hugging_face:
We Are here to help each other 🥰

There are several reasons why using MVC is the right way to develop professional applications: it tells us how to structure our project, it will give us the security tools we need, and it will also show anyone who looks into this world of mod_harbour, which we are preparing to use modern techniques that are the ones that use most of the tools on the web for other languages.
That said, you have to separate between doing a test while a user learns and aim to develop a complete web application. In the first case, it is normal to use any form of programming, which you have usually used, because in this case the important thing is that the user gets what he wants and feels motivated, since you can not ask a newcomer user to mod_harbour, in addition to learning html, css, js, etc., that you learn programming techniques with which you are not accustomed, but at the moment you start to climb steps and your tests become a thing of the past and begin to develop A serious application for the web, you must realize that you cannot and should not forget that you must use MVC to achieve a serious and professional result.

Hay varios motivos por los que utilizar MVC es el camino adecuado para el desarrollo de aplicaciones profesionales: nos indica cómo ha de estructurarse nuestro proyecto, nos dará las herramientas de seguridad que necesitamos, y también mostrará a cualquier persona que se asome a este mundo de mod_harbour, que nos vamos preparando para utilizar técnicas modernas que son las que utilizan la mayoría de herramientas que hay en la web para otros lenguajes.
Dicho esto, hay que separar entre hacer unos tests mientras un usuario aprende y, segundo, tener como objetivo el desarrollo de una aplicación web completa. En el primer caso, es normal utilizar cualquier forma de programar, la que habitualmente has utilizado, porque en este caso lo importante es que el usuario obtenga lo que quiere y se sienta motivado, ya que no se le puede pedir a un usuario recién llegado a mod_harbour, además de ir aprendiendo html, css, js, etc., que aprenda técnicas de programación con las que no está acostumbrado, pero en el momento que empiece a subir escalones y sus pruebas pasen a ser cosa del pasado y comience a desarrollar una aplicación seria para la web, se ha de dar cuenta que no puede ni debe olvidar que ha de utilizar MVC para poder conseguir un resultado serio y profesional.
I wish, we would have used this MVC technique in the development of our desktop applications. How easy it would now be to migrate our code to the web
Ojalá, hubiésemos utilizado esta técnica MVC en el desarrollo de nuestras aplicaciones de escritorio. Qué fácil sería ahora migrar nuestro código a la web

In my experience in the web, there are tools such as React that will let you *start* an application in relatively little simple code without splitting it into modules, and that's really easy for quick prototyping. But that quickly becomes unmanageable if you don't switch it to something at least close to MVC.
Then again, the post above was mostly talking about almost-Javascript-only applications, not those that are heavy on the server side.

Andreu may I ask for an example for such a application. I think many of us do never have these problems with the application the make. I only have small tasks. For example one of us wants to publish the lineup of his football team. He is not a fulltime programmer. What do you suggest?
If it's a simple application, I see the point in doing it simply, even with spaghetti code.
But when it starts getting out of hand, it's probably time to refactor the whole thing.
you are right. Therefore I suggested to focus also on mod harbour "light".
Well, there is a case for simple samples that just feature the different things that mod_harbour is capable of.
Coders then can learn from them and put them together however they like.
But probably not simple samples that just print out html code.
or that print out a table from a hash
something that shows how to use the different things that mod_harbour can do

When <@UM81W8B0Q> told me about this project he said me,  this is like php but you writte a prg.

Well,  that's great,  you can do things  like writte a common header and footer, dump  a list from the download folder or similar stuff. You only need a few prgs alone  and it save you time. Also you can use some data from a DBF or an sql query, this is a good way to start.

But here there are others that wanted to start with a pre-build basic environment, that provide  the application skeleton, and a way to allow the users to signin into the application, so they can concentrate in what they do best than anybody that is the business logic of their applications. The MCV is a way to provide this, not the only but is one may work, but there are a big bunch of working hours behind that .

Here there are a small bunch of people, helping for free in the areas they interested or have some knowledge to share with the group, so we share what we have to share and take what we tough will be more usefull

<@UNAHBRTFA>>But probably not simple samples that just print out html code. or that print out a table from a hash
something that shows how to use the different things that mod_harbour can do     Andreu this is what I mean. <@UJURBDZ6U> made a great starting page for his datatables samples. Maybe he can help to insert the existing samples to this template - or we could use SEAMAP with exension for it.
I just don't see the point on all this argumentation. mod_harbour is agnostic about coding styles. Just use whatever fits your needs. Thats the beauty of Open Source.

That was a fruitful discussion today. I have ready my mod harbor publisher.
Please look how readable this code is.

-> <http://include.ch|include.ch>

function Main()

   CheckTables()
   Controller()

return nil

//----------------------------------------------------------------------------//
-> Controller.prg

-> CheckTables.prg

-> CLASSModel.prg

-> CLASSView.prg
all working fine.
Now I have single modules - mod harbour publisher patch the files.
You don't have to care about variables. After running the publisher you have a single PRG file.

Perdón no sé que está pasando cuando intento ejecutar seamap en el servidor de carlos  <https://harbour.fourtech.es/modharbour_samples/mvc/seamap/> me da error de proxy y si lo pruebo en el linux bash se queda en blanco, en index.prg hay dos lineas marcada para no ejecutar // es normal, entiendo que deben cargar la libreria core y mercury, y si estan marcadas no se ejecutan. Pero si las libero me da error de apache.prg. Que hago mal?
Andygon a mi tambien me da el error de proxy, luego presiono F5 y ya funciona, entiendo que las "lineas marcada para no ejecutar // " son interpretadas y ejecutadas por el mod_harbour
Asi es Guillermo
Bon dia
<@UJWGTCNS3> Esto es un problema que tenemos con el server. Con F5 refrescas y funcionará.

las // indica al preprocesador de harbour como sabes no ejecutar el code, pero nosotros antes pasamos nuestro preprocesador y ejecutamos lo que hay si esta entre {% %}. Esto nos facilita cargar libs, declarar variables de entorno,...
SI no te funciona en el bash mira el htacces y las variables de definicion
El ejemplo q estais probando lo ha creado Antonio en MVC para aprender y entender el funcionamiento. Intentat seguirlo y esto sera la base para crear buenas app
El proximo ejemplo aplicado aqui será con css para que veais como se ha de usar para que encaje bien en la app
moviendo solo un fichero.css cambiara radicalmente su apariencia (botones,colores,fuentes)
buenos dias :sunny:
